subject: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering
msgSnippet: ... No, that s not it at all. 1 test did not fail and take down the other 1000. Something else outside the test suite failed and took down all 1001 tests. My
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> You just said it yourself: when you see 1001 tests failed, you know it's
> actually only 1 test that failed and it took down the other 1000.

No, that's not it at all. 1 test did not fail and take down the other
1000. Something else outside the test suite failed and took down all
1001 tests. My tests don't depend on each other but they do have shared
dependencies on things like whether the cat pulled the Ethernet cable
out of the back of my computer or the web server crashed or I moved a
third party jar file.

> Wouldn't it be nice if the framework told you exactly *which* test failed
> instead of you having to pin down which test starts the Web server or which
> tests opens a JDBC connection among thousands?

There's rarely one test that points right to this sort of problems.
There are many tests each one of which independently fails as a result
of these problems. The failure of many different tests is a clear sign
that I should look for broad environmental problems rather than specific
bugs in code.
